SCHOOL CLOSED FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE 2019-2020 SCHOOL YEAR
On April 16, 2020, the State of Wisconsin Department of Health Services ordered "Public and private K-12 schools shall remain closed for pupil instruction and extracurricular activities for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year." Therefore, the Beaver Dam Unified School District is closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.
This includes all classes, events, athletic and co-curricular activities as well as all playgrounds, fields, courts, etc. For the latest updates click here.

td.h3: Schools Closed for the Remainder of the 2019-2020 School Year
td.h6: This includes all school district playgrounds, fields, courts, etc.
td.p: On April 16, 2020, the State of Wisconsin Department of Health Services ordered "Public and private K-12 schools shall remain closed for pupil instruction and extracurricular activities for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year." Therefore, the Beaver Dam Unified School District will be closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. This includes all classes, events, athletic and co-curricular activities. This also includes all playgrounds, fields, courts, etc. The Beaver Dam Police Department will be enforcing this community safety effort and targeted alignment with the Safer at Home Order.

The Beaver Dam Unified School District and their contracted food service provider (Taher, Inc.) will be providing free meals to the community (any person 18 years or younger and persons 19 or older with a physical or mental disability, as defined by the State). Please click here for locations, dates, times and other information.

The district will work to ensure virtual learning continues for students. Digital Distance Learning syllabi and lessons will be posted each week by 4:00 pm on Friday.
BDUSD has a number of plans and resources in place to provide instruction during an extended closure. Click here for Google Classroom and other DDL information.
All BDUSD buildings and grounds have free public WiFi. The Beaver Dam Community Library also has free public WiFi. WiFi can be accessed from all building parking lots.

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Several Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are offering free or low-cost internet access options in response to the COVID-19 health emergency. Click here for a list of internet resources.

p.strong: Governor Evers is encouraging us to get outside with our children. Are we allowed to use school playgrounds and property?

p.em: No, according to the order, all playgrounds and school property is closed until May 26.

p.strong: (3/24/20) What does this mean for Advanced Placement testing?

p.em: Students who DO NOT have a device or internet connectivity for their AP exams must contact the following website ASAP: http://cb.org/tech

Click here for the 2020 AP Exam Schedule & Information. Reminder that exam fees are $94.00 each and are due by May 1st. Please contact Ms. Droessler if this is not possible or with any other questions.

p.strong: (3/24/20) Do we have to extend our school year into the summer?

div.p: No, DPI has waived the hours requirement, which means the school year will not be extended.

p.strong: (3/24/20) When will I see the syllabi for my child(ren)’s class(es)?

p.em: They will be posted every Friday by 4:00 pm. Your child will not need them until the following Monday after they are posted.

p.strong: (3/24/20) I keep getting “RESTRICTED” or “UNKNOWN CALLER” phone calls on my Caller ID. Why is this?

p.em: Our staff are calling from their personal lines, using a RESTRICTED number to protect their privacy. If you receive a call from a RESTRICTED number, please answer it, as it is likely someone from your child(ren)’s school trying to reach you or your child.

a.p: What if I need help with my district digital learning technology while I am at home? Is there a number to call or an email to contact?

li.em: Contact your child(ren)'s classroom teacher via their school phone number or email address.

If problem still persists after contacting your child(ren)'s teacher, submit a help request at ddltechsupport@bdusd.org. We will attempt to respond to help requests within 24 hours on regular business days.

p.em: Attendance is determined by a student's participation in the Digital Distance Learning opportunity as provided by the district and students are expected to engage daily in the learning.

a.p: Will there be internet locations for families available within the district for families to come and download assignments, etc.?

p.em: All BDUSD buildings and grounds have free public WiFi. The Beaver Dam Community Library also has free public WiFi. WiFi can be accessed from all building parking lots.
Some internet carriers are offering free and/or low cost options that your family may be able to use.

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Comcast Internet Essentials indicated that they are providing 60 days of free internet to qualifying families. Learn more about the Comcast offer here.

a.p: How will all of the communication go to families regarding access and other logistics relative to resources during digital/distance learning?

p.em: Each teacher will be responsible for daily communication with their families. This will be done through Google Classroom, Google Sites, Class Dojo, and/or other methods of communication as previously approved. No other forms or methods will be used by teachers for communicating with families.

a.p: How will families who do not have access to the internet receive materials at all grade levels?

p.em: All BDUSD buildings and grounds have free public WiFi. The Beaver Dam Community Library also has free public WiFi. WiFi can be accessed from all building parking lots.
Some internet carriers are offering free and/or low cost options that your family may be able to use.

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Comcast Internet Essentials indicated that they are providing 60 days of free internet to qualifying families. Learn more about the Comcast offer here.

a.p: When can we expect to receive information about summer school? (Handbooks, registration…)

p.em: Based on the information we have at this time, the District will still plan to hold summer school, but we realize that it may look differently than originally scheduled. As we know more, we will make that information available. It is quite possible that summer school will be pushed back to later dates in the summer and/or the programming may change. We hope as summer learning opportunities are shared with you, that families will support the learning endeavors of their child(ren).

td.p:
During the school closure it is important for all students and families to care for their physical and mental health. The importance of routines, self care, and overall wellness is essential. The Beaver Dam Unified School District Student services team has collected information and resources for families to use while schools are closed. A list of those resources can be found on the right side of this page. Please click here for a list of community resources. (Print version of Community Resources)
BDUSD Student Services Staff (School Counselors, School Nurses, School Psychologists, and School Social Workers) are here to help. They are available to discuss these resources and other community resources. Feel free to contact a Student Services Staff member with any questions.

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When we return to the classroom, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact your child's school office to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Dodge County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: BDUSD has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.
td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.
